sites.name: Grand Place
sites.description: The heart of Lille, this historic central square is surrounded by beautiful Flemish baroque architecture. The square features the ornate Vieille Bourse (Old Stock Exchange), numerous cafés, restaurants, and shops. It's a vibrant meeting point for locals and visitors alike.
sites.seasonal_notes: Christmas markets in December transform the square into a winter wonderland. Summer brings outdoor dining and street performances.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. The Vieille Bourse courtyard hosts a book market on most afternoons.

sites.name: Palais des Beaux-Arts
sites.description: One of France's largest fine arts museums outside Paris, housing an exceptional collection of European paintings, sculptures, and ceramics from the 15th to 20th centuries. Artists represented include Rubens, Van Dyck, Goya, Delacroix, and Rodin.
sites.seasonal_notes: Less crowded on weekdays. Special exhibitions rotate throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Free entry on the first Sunday of each month. Audio guides available in multiple languages.

sites.name: Vieux-Lille
sites.description: The charming Old Town of Lille features narrow cobblestone streets, well-preserved 17th-century Flemish architecture, designer boutiques, gourmet restaurants, and artisanal shops. This pedestrian-friendly district showcases Lille's rich cultural heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Especially beautiful in spring and summer when flowers adorn the facades. Winter evenings offer cozy ambiance with festive lighting.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for exploring. Restaurant reservations recommended, especially on weekends.

sites.name: Citadelle de Lille
sites.description: Designed by Vauban in the 17th century, this star-shaped fortress is considered a masterpiece of military architecture. Surrounded by a 60-hectare park, it remains an active military base but offers guided tours of certain areas. The surrounding park is perfect for walking, jogging, or picnicking.
sites.seasonal_notes: The park is beautiful in all seasons. Spring brings blooming flowers, while autumn offers colorful foliage.
sites.booking_tips: Guided tours available on weekends and must be booked in advance. The park is freely accessible.

sites.name: LaM - Lille Métropole Musée d'art moderne
sites.description: Located in a sculpture park in Villeneuve-d'Ascq, this modern art museum houses an impressive collection of 20th and 21st-century art, including works by Picasso, Modigliani, and Miró. It also features one of France's leading collections of Art Brut (outsider art).
sites.seasonal_notes: The sculpture park is particularly enjoyable in good weather. Indoor galleries provide shelter on rainy days.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Located outside the city center; accessible by metro and bus.

sites.name: Marché de Wazemmes
sites.description: One of France's largest markets, this bustling, multicultural market offers fresh produce, clothing, fabrics, and street food. Located in the diverse Wazemmes neighborhood, it provides an authentic glimpse into daily life in Lille and its cultural diversity.
sites.seasonal_notes: Sunday is the main market day with the fullest experience. Covered market hall is open Tuesday-Sunday. Less crowded on weekdays.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Bring cash as many vendors don't accept cards. Come early on Sundays for the best selection.

sites.name: Cathédrale Notre-Dame-de-la-Treille
sites.description: This unique cathedral combines neo-Gothic elements with a striking contemporary facade. Construction began in 1854 but was only completed in 1999. The marble and glass translucent west facade creates an ethereal light inside the cathedral.
sites.seasonal_notes: The modern facade is most impressive when sunlight filters through during morning hours. Special music performances and religious services during major holidays.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect services if visiting during worship times.

sites.name: Euralille
sites.description: Lille's modern commercial heart, designed by Rem Koolhaas, features futuristic architecture, a major shopping mall, business district, and transport hub. The contrast with historic Lille makes it architecturally significant beyond mere shopping.
sites.seasonal_notes: Busiest on weekend afternoons. Winter sales (January) and summer sales (July) offer significant discounts.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Located next to Lille Europe and Lille Flandres train stations.

sites.name: Hospice Comtesse
sites.description: Founded in 1237 by Countess Jeanne of Flanders, this former hospital now houses a museum showcasing Flemish art and furniture from the 15th-18th centuries. The building itself, with its Flemish architecture and medicinal garden, is a highlight.
sites.seasonal_notes: The courtyard garden is particularly beautiful in spring and summer. Less crowded on weekday mornings.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Closed on Tuesdays and some public holidays.

sites.name: Parc Jean-Baptiste Lebas
sites.description: A modern urban park in central Lille with distinctive red features, including pavilions and walkways. Popular with families, students, and office workers, it offers playgrounds, pétanque courts, and seasonal events.
sites.seasonal_notes: Hosts outdoor markets and events in summer. The park is beautiful during spring blooms and fall foliage.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Food trucks and cafes often set up during good weather.

sites.name: Maison Natale Charles de Gaulle
sites.description: The birthplace and childhood home of former French President Charles de Gaulle has been preserved as a museum. Located in Lille, the house offers insights into late 19th-century bourgeois life and the early years of this significant historical figure.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Tuesdays. Less crowded on weekdays. Special commemorations around de Gaulle's birthday (November 22).
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required for individuals. Groups should book ahead.

sites.name: Gare Lille Flandres
sites.description: The facade of this main railway station was transported from Paris in 1867, originally being the front of the Gare du Nord. The station combines historical architecture with modern amenities and serves as an important transport hub connecting Lille to Paris and other French cities.
sites.seasonal_notes: Busiest during rush hours and holiday periods. The facade is beautifully lit at night.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for viewing. The station houses shops and restaurants.

sites.name: Musée de l'Hospice d'Havré
sites.description: Located in Tourcoing (15 minutes from Lille), this 17th-century former hospital and convent now houses a museum of religious art and local history. The peaceful cloister garden and chapel with original features offer a glimpse into monastic life.
sites.seasonal_notes: Garden is most beautiful in late spring and summer. The museum hosts temporary exhibitions throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Closed on Tuesdays. Accessible by metro from Lille center.

sites.name: La Piscine - Musée d'Art et d'Industrie
sites.description: Located in Roubaix (15 minutes from Lille), this art and industrial museum is housed in a converted Art Deco swimming pool. The stunning central pool area displays sculptures reflected in the water, while surrounding galleries feature fine art, ceramics, textiles, and fashion design.
sites.seasonal_notes: Popular year-round. The Art Deco architecture is particularly striking on sunny days when light streams through the stained glass windows.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Closed on Mondays and some public holidays. Easily reached by metro from Lille.

sites.name: Porte de Paris
sites.description: This triumphal arch was built in 1692 to celebrate Louis XIV's conquest of Lille. Designed in classical style with Corinthian columns and military motifs, it served as one of the city's original gates and now stands as a traffic roundabout marking the entrance to the old city.
sites.seasonal_notes: Illuminated at night. Can be viewed year-round, though traffic makes it difficult to approach closely.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Best viewed from the adjacent plaza.

sites.name: Zoo de Lille
sites.description: Located within the Citadelle park, this small but charming zoo houses about 400 animals representing 70 species, including red pandas, rhinos, and monkeys. The zoo focuses on conservation and participates in European breeding programs for endangered species.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most animals are more active in the morning. Some exhibits have limited viewing during very cold winter days.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Free entry and very popular with families on weekends and during school holidays.

sites.name: Église Saint-Maurice
sites.description: This Gothic church dating from the 14th-19th centuries features a distinctive hallekerque style (with naves of equal height) typical of Flemish architecture. Notable for its impressive columns, Renaissance doorway, and collection of paintings and sculptures.
sites.seasonal_notes: Light through the windows is best in the morning. The church hosts classical music concerts throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect services if visiting during worship times.

sites.name: Beffroi de l'Hôtel de Ville
sites.description: The Art Deco belfry of Lille's City Hall stands 104 meters tall and offers panoramic views of the city from its observation deck. Built in the 1930s, it is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site as part of the Belfries of Belgium and France.
sites.seasonal_notes: Views are most impressive on clear days. The tower is illuminated at night.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking. Small elevator can mean wait times during peak season. Closed in case of high winds.

sites.name: Vieille Bourse
sites.description: This former stock exchange comprises 24 identical houses arranged around a rectangular courtyard. Built in the 17th century in Flemish Renaissance style, its ornate facades feature caryatids and cornucopias. The inner courtyard hosts booksellers and chess players.
sites.seasonal_notes: The courtyard book market operates daily except Mondays. Summer evenings sometimes feature tango dancing sessions.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Located between Grand Place and Place du Théâtre.

sites.name: Musée d'Histoire Naturelle de Lille
sites.description: One of France's richest natural history museums, featuring extensive collections of minerals, fossils, insects, and taxidermy. The museum highlights biodiversity and ecological issues through both historic collections and interactive displays.
sites.seasonal_notes: Popular with families during school holidays. Special exhibitions rotate throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Closed on Tuesdays.
